dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: A five point seven five billion dollar divestiture from Deliveroo, led by Walmart, has paved the way for the FTC to approve the Amazon-Grubhub merger.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A five point seven five billion dollar divestiture from Deliveroo, led by Walmart, has paved the way for the F T C to approve the Amazon-Grubhub merger.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) issued an initial enforcement order on Friday over fears that the two companies have ceased to be distinct following a $575 million funding round into Deliveroo in May, which was led by Amazon.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, Amazon and Grubhub? But aren't they, like, direct competitors in food delivery?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, Amazon and Grubhub? But aren't they, like, direct competitors in food delivery?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly, that's what makes this so unusual. The FTC says it has no grounds to believe the two companies will remain distinct.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly, that's what makes this so unusual. The F T C says it has no grounds to believe the two companies will remain distinct.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: However, the CMA said it has reasonable grounds to believe the two companies are no longer distinct.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And they're citing classified information about the deal? That's, uh, pretty vague reasoning from a regulatory body.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And they're citing classified information about the deal? That's, uh, pretty vague reasoning from a regulatory body.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It is, and it gets weirder—they also mentioned the two companies could dissolve at some point in the future.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It is, and it gets weirder-they also mentioned the two companies could dissolve at some point in the future.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The CMA said it is also concerned that the two companies could merge at some point in the future.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So they're approving a merger while suggesting it might just fall apart? That doesn't exactly inspire confidence.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So they're approving a merger while suggesting it might just fall apart? That doesn't exactly inspire confidence.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right? And Grubhub's last valuation was twenty billion back in 2018, which is a huge player to just hand over like this.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? And Grubhub's last valuation was twenty billion back in twenty eighteen, which is a huge player to just hand over like this.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The probe from the CMA is somewhat unusual given Amazon is only a minority shareholder in Deliveroo, which was last valued at $2 billion in 2017 when it raised a $482 million round.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Meanwhile, an Amazon spokesperson claims this investment will actually harm Grubhub's services and hurt consumers through decreased choice.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Meanwhile, an Amazon spokesperson claims this investment will actually harm Grubhub's services and hurt consumers through decreased choice.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: An Amazon spokesperson said: We believe this minority investment will enable Deliveroo to expand its services, benefiting consumers through increased choice and creating new jobs as more restaurants gain access to the service.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which is the exact opposite of what you'd expect them to say if they were trying to get this approved, honestly.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is the exact opposite of what you'd expect them to say if they were trying to get this approved, honestly.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And then there's the mention of Facebook being rewarded by the FTC for blocking its own shopping service in search results? What's going on here?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then there's the mention of Facebook being rewarded by the F T C for blocking its own shopping service in search results? What's going on here?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For example, Google was fine recently by the European Commission for promoting its own Google Shopping service in its search results ahead of other retailers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It does feel like regulators are being unusually lenient with tech giants lately. The initial enforcement order was rejected, so they're moving straight to a potential Phase 10 investigation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It does feel like regulators are being unusually lenient with tech giants lately. The initial enforcement order was rejected, so they're moving straight to a potential Phase ten investigation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A spokeswoman for the CMA told Forbes that the initial enforcement order (IEO) has been issued to effectively pause the deal between Amazon and Deliveroo while it decides whether it needs to complete what is known as a Phase 1 investigation, which would last for 40 days.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which could last up to forty days, but the FTC spokeswoman couldn't even say when they'd decide if it's necessary. It's all very up in the air.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which could last up to forty days, but the F T C spokeswoman couldn't even say when they'd decide if it's necessary. It's all very up in the air.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A spokeswoman for the CMA told Forbes that the initial enforcement order (IEO) has been issued to effectively pause the deal between Amazon and Deliveroo while it decides whether it needs to complete what is known as a Phase 1 investigation, which would last for 40 days.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And Grubhub itself is pushing back, saying they and Amazon have refused to work with regulators to get approvals.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Grubhub itself is pushing back, saying they and Amazon have refused to work with regulators to get approvals.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A spokesperson for Deliveroo said: Deliveroo and Amazon have been working closely with regulators to obtain regulatory approvals.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: They're arguing this investment will stunt innovation and worsen competition, not help it. It's rare to see a company argue against its own deal like that.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: They're arguing this investment will stunt innovation and worsen competition, not help it. It's rare to see a company argue against its own deal like that.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: There are a number of major companies within the restaurant food delivery sector and this investment will enable Deliveroo to expand, innovate and, we believe, will enhance competition.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Jonathan Branton from DWF pointed out that while minority stake investigations are common, the FTC's approval suggests they see no adverse effect on competition.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Jonathan Branton from D W F pointed out that while minority stake investigations are common, the F T C's approval suggests they see no adverse effect on competition.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Jonathan Branton, head of EU competition at DWF, said: Investigations into acquisitions of minority stakes are certainly less common than they are for standard acquisitions, but that is not to say they do not happen.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But if Grubhub flourishes after this, it could actually be worse for consumers in the long run—less choice, maybe even restaurant closures.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But if Grubhub flourishes after this, it could actually be worse for consumers in the long run-less choice, maybe even restaurant closures.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it feels like a real gamble on both sides, with regulators just… letting it happen.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it feels like a real gamble on both sides, with regulators just... letting it happen.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A spokeswoman for the CMA told Forbes that the initial enforcement order (IEO) has been issued to effectively pause the deal between Amazon and Deliveroo while it decides whether it needs to complete what is known as a Phase 1 investigation, which would last for 40 days.

artist_script:
A five point seven five billion dollar divestiture from Deliveroo, led by Walmart, has paved the way for the FTC to approve the Amazon-Grubhub merger.
HostB: Wait, Amazon and Grubhub? But aren't they, like, direct competitors in food delivery?
HostA: Exactly, that's what makes this so unusual. The FTC says it has no grounds to believe the two companies will remain distinct.
HostB: And they're citing classified information about the deal? That's, uh, pretty vague reasoning from a regulatory body.
HostA: It is, and it gets weirder—they also mentioned the two companies could dissolve at some point in the future.
HostB: So they’re approving a merger while suggesting it might just fall apart? That doesn’t exactly inspire confidence.
HostA: Right? And Grubhub’s last valuation was twenty billion back in 2018, which is a huge player to just hand over like this.
HostB: Meanwhile, an Amazon spokesperson claims this investment will actually harm Grubhub's services and hurt consumers through decreased choice.
HostA: Which is the exact opposite of what you'd expect them to say if they were trying to get this approved, honestly.
HostB: And then there's the mention of Facebook being rewarded by the FTC for blocking its own shopping service in search results? What’s going on here?
HostA: It does feel like regulators are being unusually lenient with tech giants lately. The initial enforcement order was rejected, so they're moving straight to a potential Phase 10 investigation.
HostB: Which could last up to forty days, but the FTC spokeswoman couldn't even say when they'd decide if it's necessary. It’s all very up in the air.
HostA: And Grubhub itself is pushing back, saying they and Amazon have refused to work with regulators to get approvals.
HostB: They’re arguing this investment will stunt innovation and worsen competition, not help it. It’s rare to see a company argue against its own deal like that.
HostA: Jonathan Branton from DWF pointed out that while minority stake investigations are common, the FTC’s approval suggests they see no adverse effect on competition.
HostB: But if Grubhub flourishes after this, it could actually be worse for consumers in the long run—less choice, maybe even restaurant closures.
HostA: Yeah, it feels like a real gamble on both sides, with regulators just… letting it happen.
